title: God Valley Was The Island Of Hiriluk's Cherry Blossoms
author: Worstgen Forum User
theory: This theory proposes that the island where Hiriluk experienced his miraculous healing through cherry blossoms was actually God Valley. The evidence includes: (1) Hiriluk mentioned the miracle happened in 'a faraway land in the West,' and Chapter 1095 confirmed God Valley was in the West Blue; (2) The connection between cherry blossoms and liberation/revolution, as Dragon and the Revolutionaries are introduced in a chapter called 'Skull and Cherry Blossoms'; (3) The symbolic importance of cherry blossoms representing freedom and change throughout One Piece.

title: Cherry Blossoms Represent Liberation and Revolution in One Piece
author: Multiple Fan Discussions
theory: This theory suggests that cherry blossoms (sakura) are a recurring symbol throughout One Piece representing liberation, revolution, and freedom. Evidence includes: (1) Hiriluk's cherry blossoms were meant to 'cure the hearts' of Drum Island's people, symbolizing freedom from despair; (2) The Revolutionary Army's introduction chapter is titled 'Skull and Cherry Blossoms'; (3) Drum Kingdom being renamed Sakura Kingdom after liberation from Wapol; (4) The potential connection to Wano and the symbolic meaning of 'Ryuo' (Flowing Sakura) as the term for Haki.

title: Wano's Connection to Hiriluk Through 'Ryuo' (Flowing Sakura)
author: Fan Community
theory: This theory questions why Oda chose the term 'Ryuo' (Flowing Sakura) for Haki in Wano, potentially connecting it to Dr. Hiriluk's cherry blossom research and his goal to create an elixir capable of curing all diseases. The theory suggests Wano might have deeper connections to the Drum Island arc beyond surface similarities, possibly relating to the nature of healing and power in One Piece.

title: Dr. Hiriluk Was Rocks D. Xebec (Highly Speculative)
author: Birds of Hermes
theory: This highly speculative theory proposes that Dr. Hiriluk might have been Rocks D. Xebec, based on timeline coincidences, visual similarities, and the theme of redemption. The theory notes that Hiriluk was a thief who changed after seeing cherry blossoms, and Rocks disappeared after God Valley. However, this theory is considered unlikely by most fans and lacks substantial evidence.

title: Hiriluk's Philosophy Foreshadows Major Series Themes About Death and Legacy
author: Multiple Analysts
theory: This analytical theory suggests that Hiriluk's speech about when people truly die ('when they are forgotten') serves as a foundational philosophy that explains how Oda handles character deaths throughout One Piece. The theory proposes that this moment establishes the framework for understanding inherited will, the importance of dreams, and why certain characters' deaths have lasting impact while they live on through those who remember them. This theme recurs with characters like Ace, Whitebeard, and others.
